data.title: Most Populous Combined Statistical Areas in the U.S.
data.meta_description: Combined Statistical Areas represent multiple metropolitan or micropolitan areas that have an employment interchange of at least 15 percent.
data.text:
This post may contain affiliate links. As an Amazon Associate, we earn from qualifying purchases.

The U.S. Office of Management and Budget delineates combined statistical areas. These areas are groupings of neighbouring metropolitan and micropolitan statistical areas that have economic and social links as measured by commuting to work, but at lower levels than are located among U.S. counties within individual metropolitan and micropolitan statistical areas. Combined statistical areas can be characterized as representing more significant regions that reflect wide-ranging social and economic cooperations, such as wholesaling, commodity distribution, and weekend holiday activities, as well as lower levels of daily commuting interaction.

15 Most Populous Combined Statistical Areas in the U.S.

Under the 2010 Standards for Delineating Metropolitan and Micropolitan Statistical Areas, a combined statistical area is identified when two adjacent metropolitan or micropolitan statistical areas have an employment interchange measure (EIM) of at least 15. (The EIM is defined as the sum of the percentage of employed residents of the smaller area who work in, the larger area and the rate of employment in the smaller area that is accounted for by workers who reside in, the larger region).

30 Most Populous Combined Statistical Areas in the U.S.

Below is the map of 169 combined statistical areas containing more than 550 metropolitan and micropolitan statistical areas in the United States and Puerto Rico.

The 169 Combined Statistical Areas

The Combined statistical areas ranked by population
